Introduction

Tracheomalacia is the dynamic collapse of the trachea that occurs primarily during expiration, causing transient airway obstruction.  The condition can be congenital or acquired and usually affects the intrathoracic trachea, leading to chronic cough, dyspnea, and recurrent respiratory infections.

Pathogenesis



The trachea extends from the larynx (extrathoracic) to the proximal bronchi (intrathoracic) and is supported by C-shaped hyaline cartilage rings (

Trachea
).  During normal expiration, rising pressure of the thoracic cavity exceeds the pressure of the intrathoracic airway, causing the intrathoracic airway to transiently narrow.  This narrowing is clinically insignificant because the trachea's structural integrity is maintained by the cartilaginous rings.



However, in tracheomalacia, weakness of the tracheal wall causes exaggerated airway narrowing (>50%) during expiration (

figure 2
); involvement of the mainstem bronchi is referred to as tracheobronchomalacia.  Weakness occurs due to either congenital causes (eg, intrinsic tracheal defects, in utero tracheal compression) or acquired causes (eg, repeated infection or inflammation).  Recurrent collapse of the intrathoracic trachea during expiration can lead to respiratory symptoms (eg, cough, dyspnea).  This weakness and collapse also results in reduced clearance of mucus and increases the risk of prolonged or recurrent upper respiratory infections.



The extrathoracic trachea is rarely affected in tracheomalacia, but when involved, it may lead to inspiratory stridor due to negative airway pressure with inspiration.

Risk factors



Risk factors for congenital tracheomalacia include:



  • Prematurity.
  • Congenital anomalies (eg, tracheoesophageal fistula, vascular ring).
  • Genetic syndromes (eg, trisomy 21).


Risk factors for acquired tracheomalacia include:



  • Chronic airway inflammation (eg, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], recurrent tracheobronchitis).
  • Airway injury (eg, tracheostomy, repeated intubation).
  • Chronic external airway compression (eg, mediastinal goiter or malignancy).
  • Intraluminal obstruction (eg, airway hemangioma).

Clinical presentation



The clinical presentation of tracheomalacia varies based on age.

Infants



Infants usually develop symptoms within the first few weeks of life.  Because their airways are smaller than those of older children and adults, infants often present with expiratory stridor, which may be described as noisy breathing.  A chronic, barking cough is also characteristic.  Symptoms are typically worse in supine positioning and with agitation.  Cyanotic spells during feeding or crying can rarely occur, caused by sudden airway collapse.

Children and adults



Children with tracheomalacia undiagnosed in infancy often present with chronic cough, frequent or prolonged respiratory infections, and exercise-induced dyspnea.  Adults with acquired tracheomalacia present similarly, but history usually reveals risk factors (eg, repeated intubation, COPD).  In those with severe narrowing, coughing fits may precipitate complete airway collapse and syncope.  In some cases, patients are asymptomatic, and incidental findings of tracheal wall weakness are identified during evaluation for another condition.



Extrathoracic disease is less common but can present with inspiratory stridor at any age.

Evaluation and diagnosis



Chest x-ray is generally the first step in evaluation of patients with chronic cough or stridor to assess for alternate diagnoses, such as infection, an aspirated foreign body, or malignancy.  However, the dynamic tracheal narrowing of tracheomalacia is not usually seen on x-ray.  Pulmonary function testing is also part of the initial evaluation and supports a diagnosis of tracheomalacia by showing expiratory flow reduction (eg, flat ceiling of upper half of flow volume loop) with inspiratory flow preservation (

figure 3
), suggestive of dynamic intrathoracic obstruction.



A definitive diagnosis of tracheomalacia is made via direct visualization of tracheal wall narrowing during exhalation on bronchoscopy.  Expiratory-inspiratory imaging (eg, MRI, CT scan) is also diagnostic and can help identify an underlying etiology (eg, goiter) in acquired cases.  This latter diagnostic approach is preferred when an extrinsic cause of tracheal collapse is suspected.  For example, mass effect from a vascular ring, goiter, or malignancy often presents with biphasic stridor (rather than expiratory alone) because this is a fixed obstruction.

Differential diagnosis



Alternate diagnoses to consider vary by age.

Infants



  • Laryngomalacia (
    figure 4
    ):  Decreased supraglottic airway tone can cause chronic stridor in infancy that is worse with supine positioning.  Because the dynamic obstruction is extrathoracic, stridor is inspiratory, and chronic cough is not typical.  Direct visualization of the airway will show a weakness in the larynx rather than the trachea.
  • Foreign body aspiration:  Aspiration of a foreign body into the trachea in a young child can lead to stridor and cough.  Symptoms generally have a sudden onset in a previously healthy, independently mobile child. 

Adults



  • Asthma (
    figure 5
    ):  Chronic airway inflammation and bronchial smooth muscle dysfunction can cause chronic cough and exertional dyspnea.  Symptoms rapidly improve with inhaled bronchodilators.
  • Vocal cord dysfunction:  Inappropriate vocal cord adduction during inspiration can lead to inspiratory stridor with flattening of inspiratory flow on pulmonary function testing.

Management and prognosis

Congenital



Isolated congenital tracheomalacia gradually improves and resolves by age 1-2 as the airway diameter increases and cartilage matures.  Therefore, most patients warrant observation alone.  Those with evidence of severe narrowing (which is uncommon) may require continuous positive airway pressure to maintain airway patency.

Acquired



Treatment of patients with symptomatic tracheomalacia focuses on optimizing management of any associated underlying disease (eg, vascular ring, COPD).  Adjunctive therapies include use of a flutter valve device or percussion vest to aid in sputum clearance, potentially reducing the risk of recurrent infection.  More invasive management (eg, stent placement) is considered to achieve airway stability when medical management fails.

Summary



Tracheomalacia (
